fields.label_text:
British Galleries:
Richard Gibson had been a page to Charles I, and was known as Dwarf Gibson on account of his small size. During the Commonwealth he worked among a close circle of aristocratic families. Elizabeth Capell (1633-1678), was the wife of Gibson's principal patron during the 1650s, Charles Dormer, 2nd Earl of Carnarvon (1632-1709).

fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of a woman, perhaps Elizabeth Capell, Countess of Carnarvon, watercolour on vellum, painted by Richard Gibson, 1653-1657.

fields.name: Seduced by Art: Photography Past and Present

fields.physical_description: Portrait, oval frame, the sitter turned to front and wearing a pearl necklace. Features in brown and sanguine, impasted and blended in long diagonal strokes with white, hatched and shadowed with blue, on a pale carnation ground; hair in transparent pale brown wash over the carnation with broad, dark brown gummy hatching and some gouache lights; dress in opaque blue washes lightened with white; chemise in white shaded with blue-grey; jewellery in opaque ochre, with black and white; background a yellow wash, hatched and stippled in ochre and brown, darkening in lower parts and to the right; on vellum put down on pasteboard. Frame: Seventeenth-century turned oval of ebonised fruitwood; a complex bolection moulding with additional grooves on the inner and outer ring; a slightly convex glass fitted to a rebate and the back closed with an oak backboard. The latter inscribed in ink: 1714 / Henry Portman / [illegible].
fields.dimensions: Height: 74 mm, Width: 60 mm, Height: 100 mm Frame, Width: 84 mm Frame
fields.title: Unknown Woman, perhaps Elizabeth Capell, Countess of Carnarvon
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on pasteboard
fields.label:
British Galleries:
Richard Gibson had been a page to Charles I, and was known as Dwarf Gibson on account of his small size. During the Commonwealth he worked among a close circle of aristocratic families. Elizabeth Capell (1633-1678), was the wife of Gibson's principal patron during the 1650s, Charles Dormer, 2nd Earl of Carnarvon (1632-1709). [27/03/2003]
fields.location: British Galleries, room 56d, case 3, shelf Dr1
fields.public_access_description:
Object Type
Miniature painting is defined as watercolour  on a vellum (fine animal skin) support . Most miniaturists learnt the techniques from another miniaturist. Gibson's technique however reveals a different training. Gibson was a page to the Lord Chamberlain, Philip Herbert, 4th Earl of Pembroke, and through him became a page in the Royal Household. Here Gibson met the oil painter Peter Lely (1618-1680) and was probably influenced by his technique. Unlike the other miniaturists, whose brushwork was very smooth, Gibson used a distinctive dragged impasto (thickly laid paint).

People
Gibson's work is sometimes lacking in individuality, but this image is very like other known portraits of Elizabeth Capell. It dates from 1653-1657, the period following Elizabeth's marriage to Charles Dormer, 2nd Earl of Carnarvon. He was grandson of Lord Pembroke, Gibson's longstanding patron.

Artist
For years it was thought there were two artists, one signing 'DG' and one signing 'RG'. It is now clear that the 'D' stands for 'Dick', or possibly 'Dwarf' (Gibson was only just over a metre tall).  Gibson's position at the court of Charles I was as page not miniature painter and during the Commonwealth period he remained under the care of  the Earl of Pembroke's nephew.  But at the Restoration Gibson set up independently as a miniaturist in London. He then signed more confidently 'RG'.
fields.exhibition_history:
Seduced by Art: Photography Past and Present (CaixaForum, Barcelona 22/02/2013-19/05/2013)
Seduced by Art: Photography Past and Present (National Portrait Gallery 31/10/2012-20/01/2013)
The English Miniature (Yale Center for British Art 1981-1982)
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Cat.98, pp.179-180. Full Citation: “98 Unknown Woman, perhaps Elizabeth Capell, Countess of Carnarvon (b.1633 d.1678) 1653-7 P15-1926 Oval 74x60mm Features in brown and sanguine, impasted and blended in long diagonal strokes with white, hatched and shadowed with blue, on a pale carnation ground; hair in transparent pale brown wash over the carnation with broad, dark brown gummy hatching and some gouache lights; dress in opaque blue washes lightened with white; chemise in white shaded with blue-grey; jewellery in opaque ochre, with black and white; background a yellow wash, hatched and stippled in ochre and brown, darkening in lower parts and to the right; on vellum put down on pasteboard. Condition: Zinc-white retouches on old losses in the forehead, cheeks, nose and dress; flaking in the jewellery; condensation damage in the background. A bristle from the brush remains embedded in the gummy paint of the hair. Signed: Lower centre left, in black: DC (see A in Appendix 2). Frame: Seventeenth-century turned oval of ebonised fruitwood; a complex bolection moulding with additional grooves on the inner and outer ring; a slightly convex glass fitted to a rebate and the back closed with an oak backboard. The latter inscribed in ink: 1714 / Henry Portman / [illegible]. Provenance: Anonymous vendor, Christie's 11 May 1926, lot 114 (as by ‘David de Grange'), bt Agnew on behalf of the Museum. Exhibited: New Haven etc. 1 98 1-2, no. 51. Literature: Long 1930, p.19, fig. 45 (as signed WC in monogram, attributed to Louis du Guernier); Long 1933, p. 16; Schidloff 1964, vol. 1, p. 220; Foskett 1972, vol. I, p. 254; Summary Catalogue, 1981, p. 14; Murdoch and Murrell1981, p. 288, fig. 12; Murdoch 1981, p. 133, pl. 24a. The former attribution to Louis du Guernier (1614-1659) was by Long and, before Long and Captain Pearce worked on the 'DG' problem in the early 1930s, (1) was clearly a better interpretation of the Signature than the 'David de Grange' offered in the Christies sale catalogue. In his Gazette des Beaux Arts article (2) Long published the miniature tentatively as a key part of a possible du Guernier opus: recognising the Englishness of the style in this, as in four supposedly similar miniatures in English collections, he suggested that du Guernier may have worked in England. Long died before he could sort out the DG problem, and his classification of this miniature came to be questioned only when the early works of Richard Gibson, both Signed and unsigned, were studied in connection with work on this catalogue. Presumably the works that Long recognised as similar to this miniature were also early works by Gibson; certainly, on the basis of the reproduction, one miniature illustrated as du Guernier by Schidloff (3) is a Gibson closely comparable with this miniature. Much of the previously accepted oeuvre of du Guernier has thus been stripped away, and he can be identified now as an exclusively French illuminator and enamellist. (4) Similar DG signatures are on the Unknown Man (5); datable 1648-50, this, together with a miniature in the collection ofRobert Bayne- Powell, is one of the earliest extant works of Richard Gibson. Other examples of the monogram are on the Earl and Countess of Carnarvon, datable 1653-7, in the collection of the Duke of Beaufort (6). Possibly this form of monogram in interlinked romans precedes the cursive form which appears on the back of Sir Richard Anderson of 1658 (7), which in turn precedes the very similar cursive RG of the later works – for example Lady Isabella Dormer (Cat. No. 109). The sitter for this miniature seems to bear a strong likeness to Elizabeth Capell, Countess of Carnarvon, as for example in Gibson's perhaps slightly later treatment of her in the Duke of Beaufort's miniature. The arrangement of hair on her forehead is different, but the resemblance otherwise in the set of the chin and mouth, the form of the nostrils, and the wide spacing of the eyes, goes well beyond the effect of the artist's standardising vision. The date would be 1653-7, the period immediately following Elizabeth's marriage to Charles Dormer, 2nd Earl of Carnarvon, who had recently taken on the main patronage of Dwarf Gibson from his grandfather, the 4th Earl of Pembroke (d. January 1649/50). Gibson's portraits of the members of this group all share the same sober hues of the sad-coloured Commonwealth style. In most of them, fading has increased the effect of this, but in the present miniature the sitter's bright red cheeks have survived exceptionally well. Gibson's intentions in this respect - to show his sitter in the bloom of righteous health and colour - are even more evident in a miniature of an unknown woman, also of the 1650s, (8) which is in pristine, unrestored condition. The frame of the miniature was, according to a note in the Museum file, substituted for a nineteenth-century gilt rim when it was acquired by the Museum. The present wooden frame was probably in the Museum already (in connection with the Wallop Loan perhaps; Cat. No. 97 is a portrait of Sir William Portman). The inscription therefore, with its seductively interesting reference to Henry Portman, cannot be made to bear the inferences previously suggested by the present author. (9) 1 See Murdoch and Murrell 1981,pp. 282-9. 2 Long 1933. 3 Schidloff, vol. III, pl. 179, fig. 348. 4 Correctly exemplified by the illustrations in Foskett 1972, vol II, pl. 91, figs 249-52. 5 Sotheby's 29 March 1976.lot 21 repro. 6 repro. NPG 1974, nos 199 and 200. 7 Present whereabouts unknown, repro. Murdoch and Murrell 1981, fig. 2. 8 Collection of Mrs Betty Hodgkinson. 9 In Murdoch 1981, p.133.” John Murdoch, Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the Collection of the Victoria & Albert Museum, London: The Stationery Office in association with the Victoria & Albert Museum, 1997. Cat.98, p.179-180. The inscription therefore, with its seductively interesting reference to Henry Portman, cannot be made to bear the inferences previously suggested by the present author. (9) 1 See Murdoch and Murrell 1981,pp. 282-9. 2 Long 1933. 3 Schidloff, vol. III, pl. 179, fig. 348. 4 Correctly exemplified by the illustrations in Foskett 1972, vol Il, pl. 91, figs 249-52. 5 Sotheby's 29 March 1976.lot 21 repro. 6 repro. NPG 1974, nos 199 and 200. 7 Present whereabouts unknown, repro. Murdoch and Murrell l981, fig. 2. 8 Collection of Mrs Betty Hodgkinson. 9 In Murdoch 1981, p.133.” Kingsley, Hope with contributions by Riopelle, Christopher Seduced by art : photography past and present London: National Gallery, 2012
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Anonymous vendor, Christie's 11 May 1926, lot 114 (as by ‘David de Grange'), bt Agnew on behalf of the Museum.
